issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies that Animal.messageOnFeed() is an abstract method that returns a String (e.g., expected return values "Arf Arf!", "Oink!", "Maah!"). However, the solution repository changes the abstract declaration in Animal to return a FeedResponse object (Animal.messageOnFeed(): FeedResponse) and implements Pig and Seal to return FeedResponse instances. This is a cross-artifact method return-type mismatch: students reading the problem will expect to work with Strings (and to print them directly in singFarmSong and feedAllAnimals), but the solution introduces a new FeedResponse type, which is not mentioned in the problem or the template and changes how the method must be implemented and used. This deviation can confuse students and obstruct straightforward implementation of the song and feed-printing logic.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method return type across artifacts. Two reasonable fixes: (A) Revert to the problem specification: change Animal.messageOnFeed() to return String and update Pig and Seal to return String (remove FeedResponse class). This keeps the exercise simple and matches the UML/text and the intended printing usage in singFarmSong and feedAllAnimals. Or (B) If FeedResponse is intentionally introduced, update the problem statement and template to document FeedResponse (its purpose and toString behavior) and change all example text to expect a FeedResponse; ensure all animals and song-printing code use FeedResponse consistently. Option A is recommended to preserve the original educational intent (strings representing animal sounds).

issues.description: Within the solution repository there is an internal inconsistency: Animal.messageOnFeed() is declared to return FeedResponse, but Goat.messageOnFeed() is implemented to return a String. This mismatch between the abstract declaration and the Goat implementation will cause compilation errors and is an unintentional structural inconsistency inside the solution itself.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution internally consistent. Either: (1) Change Goat.messageOnFeed() to return FeedResponse (wrap the string in a FeedResponse) so it matches Animal, Pig, and Seal; or (2) Preferably (and to match the problem), change Animal to declare messageOnFeed(): String and update Pig and Seal to return String (remove or stop using FeedResponse). Ensure all implementations and usages (printing in Farm.singFarmSong and feedAllAnimals) are updated accordingly.

issues.description: The problem statement specifies an abstract method messageOnFeed() that returns a String (UML and task text). The solution repository, however, declares Animal.messageOnFeed() to return a FeedResponse object and introduces a FeedResponse class; two subclasses (Pig, Seal) return FeedResponse while Goat returns a String. This changes the expected contract for messageOnFeed across artifacts and is likely to confuse students: the problem and template describe/expect a String-returning message, while the solution mixes a new FeedResponse type and inconsistent overrides. This mismatch makes it unclear what students should implement and may break tests or understanding of the exercise.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method contract consistent across artifacts. Either: (A) revert the solution to match the problem/template by changing Animal.messageOnFeed() to return String and update Pig, Seal (and Goat) to return String messages (remove FeedResponse), or (B) update the problem statement and template to explicitly use FeedResponse as the return type and document the FeedResponse class. Prefer option A to minimize cognitive load and match the exercise description.
